Cedric Beust wrote:

> In JUnit, you have four ways to initialize / tear down your test, and they
> are *all* equivalent:
> 
> - At the beginning and end of each test method
> - In setUp()/tearDown()
> - In the constructor
> - At the field declaration level
> 
> I find that confusing as hell, so I *strongly* recommend to use
> setUp/tearDown at the exclusion of everything else.  Again, the idea is to
> make the intent obvious.

I prefer the opposite. Use anything except setUp/tearDown. Constructors, 
field initializers, and local variables are all standard parts of Java 
that every competent Java programmer immediately understands. 
setUp()/tearDown() is the odd one out. It is a special thing that only 
works in JUnit. Since it doesn't do anything the other three don't, why 
reinvent the wheel?
